reasoning: The critique targets a supporting premise of the essay’s second main pathway to mostly-great futures (partial AM-convergence + moral trade): that transaction/coordination costs will be extremely small relative to gains in a post-AGI world. If that premise failed, the optimism about trade would be meaningfully weakened, though the broader position wouldn’t fully collapse because the essay also discusses other routes (and already notes other blockers like threats/power concentration). The objection is substantively relevant—preference elicitation/verification over complex outcome spaces is a real hard problem—but it overstates what trade requires (full explicit utility functions over cosmic configurations) and overstates the implied resource cost (superintelligent agents can use compressed representations, approximate bargaining, narrow-domain trades, and institutionally standardized “currencies” of value; costs can fall with available compute and better algorithms). Thus it weakens rather than refutes. The critique is clear, focused, and has little fluff, but includes speculative/arguably incorrect claims about scaling and “consuming most resources,” lowering correctness and strength.
title: Specifying preferences over cosmic outcome spaces may consume prohibitive resources
